bibl.title: Letter from Alexander L. Seth to William Houston Lazear, August 27, 1920

div1.p: Seth informs William Lazear that Windsor Mansion is being sold and its contents divided among family members.

div1.head: Letter from Alexander L. Seth to William Houston Lazear, August 27, 1920
div1.opener:
Windsor Mill Farm, HFD 5 Woodlawn
Baltimore, Md., 27 August 1920.
Mr. William Houston Lazear,
(For himself, Mother and Sister)
218 Padre St.,
Santa Barbara, California.
Dear Houston,
div1.p:
Mr. Frederick J. Singley has asked me to reply
further to your letter to him of 24 June 1920.

Enclosed find copy of letter and circular from
Gilman, Son & Co., Inc. You see that they refer only to a
Promise of 10 % of the claim.

Cousin Christine and Sister made up a lists of
various articles which lists they called inventories, (although
a rather technical term). In these lists were included pictures
and books your Grandmother, my Aunt Charlotte Clayland Lazear
Sweitzer, gave me. I have thanked Cousin Christine and Sister
for sending you these lists, because I am sure that this will
enable you, your Mother and Sister to say which you wish sent to
each of you. Owing to the planned new assortment of inhabi-
tants of Windsor Mansion, a cleaning up is taking place of the
contents of the attic, &c., even from the days when Grandfather
Lazear was in Congress, and collected books. Hence we would
like to know to whom each assortment of these articles should
be sent, and what expense of insurance in addition to freight
each of you wish to pay.

Please let each of you say in your next mailing
of a letter definitely that I am free to dispose of the remain-
der of the lists as I see fit, and say which of you has the
keeping of the enclosed Gilman correspondence.
div1.closer: Yours with good wishes, Alexander L. Seth.
